video.title: Getting Your First Developer Job
video.description:
Christine recently got her first developer job. She shares her story of becoming a web developer and talks about what she did to get her first job.
  
Talk by Christine Phung at the freeCodeCamp OKC meetup. Thanks to Techlahoma for giving us permission to share.

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://medium.freecodecamp.org

replies.author: Mark B
replies.text:
4 years self taught and also went to a bootcamp. Been through about 100 applications and only 10 interviews. And I have a portfolio to backup my knowledge and git repos. I always make it to the 2nd interview which is technical, always say they like my work ethic, my clean code and structure and overall they like me. If they "liked me" so much why don't they ever contact me back for the final interview?

Not to sound sexist or mean, but you mean to tell me that someone hired this young lady with no experience, no work ethic and no skills and she still got to keep her job?

Sorry but this is an insult to hard working people that can't even get their foot in the door because of some other factor that has nothing to do with coding skills. 

I just don't get it. What is it that I lack that this person with low level to almost no skills has that I don't?

replies.text: Exactly. Cant even get an interview.

replies.author: Tyler Braden
replies.text: Alan Turing proved you wrong almost a whole century ago. For an algorithm to design and implement another algorithm it would have to solve the halting problem. Ransomware mutates its code base but that's not the same thing at all. Files and even algorithms can be generated by another algorithm but their implementation is already defined under the hood so to speak (thinking jflex and cup). We're not going to see automated programming until computers can learn how to utilize abstraction to solve problems and how to define a program that will halt.

replies.author: n2fole00
replies.text: @Sonny Brown I recommend to apply to not only companies that are hiring, but also companies that are not hiring. Internships are a great way to get experience and possibly land yourself a job at the company you are interning at. If you can afford it, try freelancing. Offer your first 2 contracts for free, and gradually increment your prices. I've never done freelancing on my own, but I have done a few freebies for clients to get some practice.
